section.title: Problem
section.para: You need a method to split your document into several modules and put it together afterwards.

section.title: Solution
section.para:
There are two methods
Actually there is another method to use, the external entities. You can read about them in The Definitive Guide at . External entities can still be used, but they have a some disadvantages so they are not described here. XIncludes are the preferred method nowadays. to solve your problem:

Assemblies are a very new method (as of November 2011) to combine modules from topics. It goes far beyond XIncludes and you need DocBook 5 and XSLT 2, but are currently under development. If you want to get more information about assemblies, read in The Definitive Guide.

XIncludes are a W3C specification and defines the elements xi:include and xi:fallback. They are not DocBook elements, however they have been integrated in DocBook 5.x
To use XInclude with DocBook 5.x, use the docbookxi.rnc RELAX NG schema. .

The file is referenced by the href attribute. Before you can transform your document, you need to resolve your XIncludes. The following procedure shows a typical workflow:

step.para: Write your document structure, usually it will be a book or an article. Do not forget to include the XInclude namespace http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude into the root element.
Add xi:include elements for those elements you want to maintain in a separate file. Typically, this can be an appendix, chapter, preface, glossary, or any other top level elements.

Resolve your XIncludes. Use a XML parser who supports XIncludes, for example, xmllint from the libxml2 library. This XML parser brings the --xinclude option to resolve all your XInclude elements in one step:

section.title: Discussion
section.para: XIncludes are a very convenient way to modularize your document. However, if the referenced file is not available, the XInclude step will fail. What can you do? The XInclude specification definies two elements: xi:include and xi:fallback. The latter can be used to add code when a ressource could not be retrieved:
section.programlisting: <xi:include href="revhistory.xml"> <xi:fallback> <para>The revision history could not be retrieved.</para> </xi:fallback> </xi:include>
section.para: The previous code does the following: When XInclude are being resolved, the XML parser tries to include the file revhistory.xml. If the file can not be retrieved, it will process the xi:fallback element and include the contents.
